name: Selaginella agioneuma
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.7717/peerj.4708 the specific epithet derives from the Greek 'Agio pnévma' meaning holy spirit and is in reference to the Brazilian State from which it was collected

name: Selaginella alstonii
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.50.4873 Named after Arthur Hugh Garfit Alston.

name: Selaginella altheae
distribution: Venezuela (Northern South America, Southern America);Colombia (Western South America, Southern America);Amazonas (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.91.21417 the species name dedicated to the author's mother, Althea Quintero

name: Selaginella boomii

reference: Bol. Commiss. Geogr. Estado Sao Paulo 2(5): 124, t.11, f.2. 1898
publication: Bol. Commiss. Geogr. Estado Sao Paulo

distribution: Brazil, acc. to Fedde, Brazil (Southern America)

name: Selaginella kriegeriana
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.1600/036364418X697643 This species is named in honor of the priest Dr. Leopoldo Krieger.

name: Selaginella magnafornensis
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Selaginella manausensis
reference: Bol. Mus. Paraense Emilio Goeldi, N.S., Bot. 45: 2(-3), figs. 1974
publication: Bol. Mus. Paraense Emilio Goeldi, N.S., Bot.

name: Selaginella monticola
distribution: São Paulo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);

name: Selaginella mucronata
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Selaginella nanuzae
distribution: São Paulo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.57.6489 ; this species is named for Professor, Dra. Nanuza Luiza de Menezes

name: Selaginella neospringiana
distribution: Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.57.6489 ; the specific epithet honors Anton Friedrich Spring (1814–1872), a German physician and botanist

name: Selaginella pellucidopunctata
distribution: Alagoas (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);Pernambuco (Brazil Northeast, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.57.6489 ; the specific epithet is derived from the Latin pellucidus, meaning translucent, and punctatus

name: Selaginella salinoi
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.11646/phytotaxa.224.3.8 , the species is named in honor of Dr. Alexandre Salino

name: Selaginella saltuicola
distribution: Mato Grosso (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America)

name: Selaginella sellowii
distribution: Praia de San Diago, Brazil (Southern America)
remarks: The LT. information is from McVaugh, Fl. Novo-Galiciana 17: 428. 1992.

name: Selaginella sematophylla
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);Rio de Janeiro (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America);

name: Selaginella squamulosa
distribution: Venezuela (Northern South America, Southern America);Amazonas (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.91.21417 the specific epithet derives from the Latin “squamulosus”, meaning minutely scaly and refers to the tiny, stiff leaves that resemble small scales

name: Selaginella stomatoloma
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.57.6489 ; the specific epithet is derived from the Greek stoma, meaning mouth, and loma, fringe or border; together these refer to the many stomata found on leaf margins

name: Selaginella terezoana
reference: Bol. Mus. Paraense Emilio Goeldi, N.S., Bot. 45: [1] (-2), figs. 1974
publication: Bol. Mus. Paraense Emilio Goeldi, N.S., Bot.

name: Selaginella trygonoides
distribution: Minas Gerais (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
remarks: doi:10.3897/phytokeys.57.6489 ; the specific epithet is derived from the Latin “trigon/trygonus”, meaning stingray; it alludes to the shape of the median leaf, which resembles these marine fish

name: Selaginella zartmanii
remarks: doi:10.7717/peerj.4708 the specific epithet honours Professor Dr. Charles Eugene Zartman
